comments.commentBody: The title of this bothers me. I don't like the thought of taking good care of children because it increases our economy. I would like to see better child care for everyone, but I would also like to see more concern for child development for  altruistic reasons. You cannot measure the bottom line using our children.

This article's robotic, horse-blinder focus on only the economics ignores many other benefits in leaving the workplace and staying home: the parent/child bond, the career clarity that comes when you step away from your job for a few years, the improvements that a stay-at-home parent can devote to the household.

It's not always about money. In fact, most parents recognize that their relationship with their children is more important than money.

There is only one viable, and immediately beneficial way for working parents to afford childcare, and it is far and away above any plan that involves tax deductions, which as we all know, including the editors, benefits mostly those who do not need the benefit, the rich.

Hillary should climb down off her throne, still under construction, make a statement which unequivocally states that a $15 per hour minimum wage is absolutely necessary, and will be a central tenet of her first hundred days in office, and further it will be nationwide, with annual cost of living increases tied to "real" inflation, as opposed to the government issued fictitious number.

And lasting further evidence of her claim that she is committed to serve the people, responsible for her possible election, is to further state that Social Security benefits will be increased to reflect the reality of the cost of living for our retired persons, adjusted annually, and not with fictitious numbers, and she must agree to a nationalized Healthcare system for all, such as Medicare.

Such unequivocal actions will guarantee her the Presidency, and restore trust in government.

Can she do it ? She most definitely can; will she, that remains to be seen.

Time to show her hand, a hand that incidentally will also put to rest, largely, whether we can trust her.

Can we trust you ??

We paid $1,500 - 2,000 per month (depending on where we lived) for good full-time pre-K childcare. The yearly tax deduction for such care is $600. So nearly all the costs are born by the parents.

My wife is from Sweden. Her sisters have paid the equivalent of $125 per month for childcare, the rest of the cost is subsidized by the state. This cost is pegged to income but maxes out at ~$185 per month even for more than one child. The Swedes also have generous maternity leave, up to 18 months split between both parents at 80% pay.

They have excellent health care, public transportation systems and are currently building a new massive circular subway line in Stockholm to improve connectivity.

For its small size, Sweden has many internationally competitive and large corporations and an excellent quality of life. How do they do it? People and corporations pay higher taxes that go to support increased productivity, health benefits, child care, and overall quality of life. They don't have a political party or parties that predominantly favor the rich with massive tax benefits.

Seen in this light, the rich in the U.S. are more like burdens on society, who sequester a massive amount of capital. This ultimately harms progress, productivity, and the greater public good.

Quality daycare is probably the best investment, by far for social stability, security and income equality. It is also the best long term investment that will keep on giving for a very long time. It is the simplest way to give entire new generations the footing to bring about positive and lasting changes.

Compared to building more bombs, more destruction machines, generating more maimed depressed veterans, or, more brutal law enforcement that makes people even more aggravated, or, more super private jails and a long list of other short-term palliative programs designed to appease rather than fix the root problems.The choice is self evident.

Quality day care is the first step for solving a great number of endemic iniquities that are inflicting great damage on society. I am a witness of the intellectual and material wealth that a simple move like that does in fact create. It gave us the digital age with more exciting things to come. More importantly it gives us a stable society. I totally agree with the content of this article it makes total sense.

To make this convincing to American voters, use real people, real life, concrete examples from countries where child care is available at affordable prices to all.

Include testimony on how they pay for it, what effect it has on their family well being and income, and what would happen to them if they lost this subsidy?

Also get some statements from politicians of all parties---why do they support it, instead of opposing it, like so many in the US?

International comparisons, if publicized properly in the media, with interviews with people from abroad, could eventually lead to better understanding of how to do it, and thus put pressure on our lawmakers.

It’s no good just saying we can’t do it, because people don’t want to pay child care workers adequately.
Proper funding by supportive govts ensures decent wages for child care workers, and leads to safety and security in the system. As in all things.

The opposite leads to the opposite---bad systems, which people than use to justify opposition to it. This goes for many things, from health care to education.

Health care for all leads to fewer deaths, and disabilities, keeping breadwinners supporting their families. Subsidized state college tuition, as we once had, leads to people getting into more skilled higher paying jobs, and then paying higher tax revenues back to the states. It’s called investment, which our history shows, creates far reaching positive cycles, paying dividends into the future.

I am livid, appalled. The American right and the left have both lost their senses. The right is led by insane beliefs, and the left is guided by every hard luck story and anecdote. The only difference is, the right wants to pick who gets free stuff, and the left wants to pick who pays for the free stuff.

And that segment of responsible Americans (quite a few actually) who live within their means, invest wisely, take care of their responsibilities, and carry quite a bit of the burden of moving this country forward - must now pay for others' rights to have children they may not afford. What on earth?

Let me see: having children is your divine right, but raising them is my responsibility as a citizen? Childcare should be free, schools are free, college should be free, healthcare should be free. Home mortgages should be subsidized. Why can't you live within your means? Most people on the planet do.

I know the next generation is important. But people have been working for a while, and the species has survived.

If I must pay for your children for ever, then you must pay for some of my choices about homes and cars I buy for ever. Why are your choices more important than my choices?

I could put forth a strong data-based argument that you subsidizing my choices is better for the economy in the short and long run, than me subsidizing your children forever.

Now I am really mad.

Kalidan

As a single taxpayer, another program I have to help subsidize because I decided I did not want to raise a family? The government's mentality that because single earners do not have to support a family, they have to support others who do.

Right now I pay taxes to schools I do not use, families to get earned income credit, having Pre-K shoved down my throat, and now child care.

I should be getting credit for not adding to the world's overpopulation, and carbon footprint, as opposed being penalized because I chose my desired lifestyle.

Yes, this sounds selfish. But, no one told parents, or would be parents, to have children; it was their choice. But, again, the government is going to ask me to fork out more, because it costs too much to raise a kid and our economy now requires both parents to work.

Meanwhile, instead of dealing with income disparity, and greed at the top, the government wants more blood out of a very dry stone.

All the comments "I don't want to pay for your children..."

Amazing.

I'm fine with that as long as we can put you on an ice floe and push you out to sea when you hit 67.

When I was a young child, and I admit it was a long time ago- in the 40s and 50s- my mother never worked nor did the mothers of any of my cousins or friends. The only women who worked, so it seemed to me, were nurses and teachers who were almost always single , usually older, women. My father was just a factory worker but we got by okay. It is true that we did not have all the things that young people today feel they must have but we did have a full time mother in the house, which was invaluable...Young people should have to decide between having children or having more things. Taxpayers should not be involved in that decision.

Why not go all the way -
Paid parental leave for both parents for six months;
Publically funded child care to age 3;
Publically funded Pre K through 12th Grade;
Publically funded colleges or trade schools.

Parents still need support once kids are school age.  When my child made this transition, I found that most of the women had to change jobs because after school care hours were shorter than daycare hours.  Therefore, those commuting to the city had to cut out that commute by getting a job closer to home.

You obviously haven't met women who have tried to resurrect their careers after a "mommy gap". Most of them end up with part-time work that doesn't come any where near their pre-mom income trajectory.

Women live longer than men, and therefore need to save more for their retirement. How can they do this when their income is so reduced?
If you own a home and take the mortgage interest deduction and property tax credit you, too, enjoy publicly subsidized housing. Enjoy!

@Kalidan

These are trade-offs for a better society and a booming economy. Almost all of us pay school taxes--whether we send our kids to independent schools or whether our kids are grown--because society benefits from an educated populace. And may I remind you of all the items you deduct on your income tax return to which I might object? However many homes you own, your mortgage interest deduction, limited to around a million dollars, is deductible; gifts you make to charities of your selection are deductible. If you decide to live in a super-expensive retirement community, the portion of your payments that are determined to be health-related are deductible. We all pay for each other's choices in ways large and small in order to spread the benefits and burdens of living in the society we have created.

Mommy can have great intelligence and talents that go beyond making and rearing babies. She should be able to do both, like I do. I grew up poor and am now a physician taking care of those in need, and have two children who are in college and planning lives of service because both their parents were examples of this kind of life. If it were not for affordable and safe childcare, this country would have one less physician who takes care of those who are less fortunate. And trust me, we need every physician like me that we have. My sons are my biggest champions. They are grateful and happy for the path that I chose. Every human should be able to live their dream. Our country is poorer when it asks people to live smaller lives than they are capable of living. Perhaps you should be forced by societal insecurities to stay home and rear children and see the impact it has on you before you decide what women can and can't do.

Childcare is a full time job, requiring maturity, patience, focus and selflessness. Ideally, one of the parents should be the primary caregiver for children. It is the profession that will ultimately have the most effect on the future. It is tragic that we don't have a society that can treasure, with both financial security and societal respect, those who care for our children.

One income families is the answer. Raise the minimum wage so that a full time worker can support a family.

Aaron, the economy has changed quite a lot since the 1940s and 1950s. That factory job your father had? Probably doesn't exist now. And if it does it's unlikely to pay enough to support a family.

Two parents work now because they want more "things"? Yeah, here are some of those things, all of which were *much* cheaper 70 years ago: housing, health care, college, retirement. Those are the things it takes two incomes to afford now.

Amazing to see how many Americans believe that children are a luxury only wealthy people deserve, because only they can afford to pay 100% of the costs to raise a child. Lots of people don't want to pay a red cent for other people's children to be brought up to become productive members of society.

Meanwhile, many people complain when immigrants are needed to come in and do the jobs that there aren't enough trained local workers to do. Why don't we have enough educated Americans to do those jobs, people say.

There's a logic gap here...

My Niece has four children, who were at one point all under the age of 6. She and her husband were cash negative at the end of each month, trying to school them in pre school, and she and her husband both working full time.

Add to that the endless nightmare of schedule juggling with full time work, the pull of loyalty between the job and and their children.

It made more sense for my niece to stay at home, create a literature rich playroom in their small house, a back yard to play in with a vegetable garden, and living frugally.

It has worked out very well, and as the children enter elementary school they are doing very well.

I worked as a preschool director for 18 years, and saw first hand the stress that parents go through-and their children-leaving their kids in a pre school 8 to 10 hours a day.

And pre-school-no matter how enriching-is not just the answer to the future success of children. Quality elementary school, junior high school, senior high school and a stable and nurturing home environment all play a vital role in a child's ability to confidently walk out the door in young adulthood, and succeed in college or a vocational training program.

The government's roll in all this would be to ensure economic and tax policy that allows time off for parents with new borns, subsidized child care, and ample money for all schools-for teacher training, sports uniforms and new books for the library-things parents are sometimes asked to subsidize.

To all those commenters and people who don't want to pay taxes to support other people's children because you made a choice to be childless:

When you are old and infirm and childless, who will care for you? Doctors, nurses, nursing home staff, lawyers, social workers, cab drivers, bus drivers - the list goes on - are all OTHER PEOPLE'S children, lovingly raised with sacrifice from their parents to care for YOU, to pay taxes for your social security which they will never reap. If you think you can live without other people's children then that means you think you can live without human society. And therefore I expect you are writing your NY Times comments from a computer you built yourself, in a lean-to deep in the woods or on a deserted island, where you subsist on nuts and berries. If that's not the case, then quit whining about other people's kids and do your part for this project called humanity.

Good quality care can make a huge difference to families with disabled children. Both my parents worked commission only sales jobs. They worked long days nights and weekends to make their sales goals. It fell to my sister and I to do school pick ups, doctor appointments, speech therapy sessions, and arrange sporting activities for our disabled younger autistic half brother. Once our brother reached the teenage years our parents could not decide on whether to medicate him or send him away to an alternative school. The family therapist had to make the decision that was putting extreme stress on the marriage and entire family. Every five years my parents had to make major decisions regarding my brothers long term care. Once he aged out of school at 21 he ended back at home in a local adult day care program. My parents could not decide on a group home for him. Having him at home long term had it's challenges once my mother came home from work to find our father in a medical emergency and my brother unable to telephone for help. My sister and I did our part but as adults we had careers, husbands and small children. Once our father past away it was clear our mother wasn't coping well. We encouraged her to move closer to her friends and family in Italy. Now she has companionship, a 24/7 adult boarding school for my brother and good quality free healthcare. She has been there two years and is very happy with her decision.
